Package main

Class Parser

java.lang.Object
main.Parser
public class Parser extends Object
This class is a recursive-descent parser which provides functionality for parsing scripts written in robbie instruction language and interpreting them from instructions into CommandInterface commands to control robbie and the RobbieApp environment.

The structural rules of the robbie instruction language are documented in the EBNF document.

Author:
Jared Schimpf

  • Constructor Details

    • Parser

      public Parser(RandomAccessFile file, CommandInterface commandInterface) throws Exception
      Constructor
      Parameters:
      file - The file to be read, which contains the robbie instruction script
      commandInterface - Interface which handles the socket connection, used to send commands to the RobbieApp
      Throws:
      Exception

  • Method Details

    • start

      public void start() throws Exception
      Initiates the parsing and interpretation process
      Throws:
      Exception - if parsing or execution fails

    • parseProgram

      private void parseProgram() throws Exception
      Outermost layer of recursive descent. A program is defined as any number of procedures followed by a single main.

      This method first checks for any procedures and calls their parsing method, then calls for the parsing method for main

      Throws:
      Exception - if parsing or execution fails

    • parseMain

      private void parseMain() throws Exception
      Main is defined by "main" followed by 1 or more instructions enclosed in curly braces

      For the sake of code reusability, the logic for interpreting multiple instructions inside a curly brace has been seperated into its own method since it is used in other parsing besides main.

      Throws:
      Exception - if parsing or execution fails

    • parseProc

      private void parseProc() throws Exception
      A procedure is defined by "proc" followed by a name, followed by 1 or more instructions enclosed in curly braces.

      this method stores the location and name of the procedure in the procMap, which will be referred back to whenever the stored procedure is called.

      Throws:
      Exception - if parsing or execution fails

    • parseInstr

      private void parseInstr() throws Exception
      An instruction is defined as the following:

      - Any number of commands

      - A conditional: if, while, do

      - A procedure call

      - An init call

      - A print statement

      Throws:
      Exception - If an unrecognized instruction is given, or if parsing or execution fails

    • parsePrint

      private void parsePrint() throws Exception
      A print statement is defined as "print" followed by a string, followed by a ";" The print instruction will print messages to the local machine, not the host machine.
      Throws:
      Exception - if parsing or execution fails

    • parseStr

      private String parseStr() throws Exception
      A string is defined as any number of characters enclosed by quotation marks
      Returns:
      the parsed string
      Throws:
      Exception - if the parsed token is not a valid string, or if parsing or execution fails

    • parseInit

      private void parseInit() throws Exception
      An initialization call is defined by "init" followed by either "grid" and a string representing the grid file name or "gems" and an integer representing an amount, then it is ended by a ";"
      Throws:
      Exception - if the parsed token after "init" is unrecognized, or if parsing or execution fails

    • parseCall

      private void parseCall() throws Exception
      A procedure call is defined by "call" followed by a name representing the procedure the call, then a ";"

      The calling of a stored procedure is handled by saving the current file pointer location, then moving the pointer backwards to where the procedure's body is defined and executing the instructions in its body. The parser then jumps back to the saved pointer location after the procedure call.

      Throws:
      Exception - if parsing or execution fails

    • parseDo

      private void parseDo() throws Exception
      A do loop is a type of conditional with two definitions, a single instruction and multi-line definition:

      - Single instruction: "do" followed by an integer and an instruction

      - Multiline": "do" followed by an integer, and then 1 or more instructions enclosed by curly braces

      A do loop will execute the instructions in its body a number of times specified by the integer given after "do"

      Throws:
      Exception - if parsing or execution fails

    • parseInteger

      private int parseInteger() throws Exception
      An integer is defined as 1 or more digits. This method attempts to parse a token as an integer, throwing an error if it fails.
      Returns:
      integer value of the token
      Throws:
      Exception - if the token cannot be parsed as an int

    • parseWhile

      private void parseWhile() throws Exception
      A while loop is a type of conditional with two definitions,a single instruction and multi-line definition:

      - Single instruction: "while" followed by a test and an instruction

      - Multiline": "do" followed by a test, and then 1 or more instructions enclosed by curly braces

      A while loop will execute the instructions in its body in a loop until the test that is specified after the "while" returns false.

      The parsing of a while loop has been split into two separate methods as a consequence of handling the problem with recursion. This method simply consumes the "while" token and initiates the looping conditional parse of the while statement's body

      Throws:
      Exception - if parsing or execution fails

    • whileLoop

      private void whileLoop() throws Exception
      Internal logic for the while loop. This method stores the pointer at the start of the loop declaration before the test is parsed, then executes the body of the loop dependent on the result of the test. If the test returns true, this method then returns to the saved pointer location and calls itself again. This forms a recursive execution loop for as long as the test condition remains true.
      Throws:
      Exception - if parsing or execution fails

    • parseIf

      private void parseIf() throws Exception
      An if statement is a type of conditional with two definitions,a single instruction and multi-line definition:

      - Single instruction: "if" followed by a test and an instruction

      - Multiline": "if" followed by a test, and then 1 or more instructions enclosed by curly braces

      An if statement will execute the instructions in its body only if its test condition returns true.

      An if statement may be followed by an optional else statement, which follows similar syntactical rules:

      - Single instruction: "else" followed by an instruction.

      - Multiline": "else" followed by 1 or more instructions enclosed by curly braces

      Throws:
      Exception - if parsing or execution fails

    • parseInstr

      private void parseInstr(boolean cond) throws Exception
      This method handles parsing or skipping an instruction depending on a passed in boolean condition
      Parameters:
      cond - the condition to check before executing
      Throws:
      Exception - if parsing or execution fails

    • parseMultilineInstr

      private void parseMultilineInstr(boolean cond) throws Exception
      This method handles parsing or skipping a multi-line (curly brace) instruction depending on a passed in boolean condition
      Parameters:
      cond - the condition to check before executing
      Throws:
      Exception - if parsing or execution fails

    • parseMultilineInstr

      private void parseMultilineInstr() throws Exception
      This method handles parsing a multi-line instruction, which is one or more instructions that exist inside the execution body of a term (such as a conditional or a procedure, or main itself) and are enclosed by curly braces.
      Throws:
      Exception - if parsing or execution fails

    • conditionalParse

      private void conditionalParse(boolean cond) throws Exception
      This method checks whether the following token is the beginning of a multi-line instruction or a single instruction, and calls the relevant condition based parsing method. This method exists to isolate some repeated logic that was used in multiple parsing methods
      Parameters:
      cond - the condition to check before executing
      Throws:
      Exception

    • parseTest

      private boolean parseTest() throws Exception
      A test is a command that returns a boolean value based on a condition in the RobbieApp environment

      A test is syntactically defined as an optional "!" or "not" symbolizing a negation, followed by one of the following test conditions:

      "leftclear" | "rightclear" | "frontclear" | "backclear" | "seejem" | "hasjem" | "facingN" | "facingW" | "facingS" | "facingE"

      Returns:
      boolean result of the test
      Throws:
      Exception - if an unrecognized test condition is give, or if parsing or execution fails

    • parseCommands

      private void parseCommands() throws Exception
      Within the EBNF the definition of 'commands' and a single 'command' is different. Commands are defined by a single command, followed by any additional commands, ended with a ";".

      The purpose of this phrasing is to show that if multiple singular commands are written on the same line, a semicolon is only needed at the end of the line, rather than after every command

      Throws:
      Exception - if parsing or execution fails

    • parseCommand

      private void parseCommand(String token) throws Exception
      A single command is defined as any single instance of the following:

      "step" | "turnL" | "turnR" | "take" | "drop"

      Each of these commands corresponds to an action robbie will take in the environment

      Parameters:
      token - the token to parse
      Throws:
      Exception - if an unrecognized command is parsed, or if command execution fails

    • parseName

      private String parseName() throws Exception
      A name is defined by the following regex: [A-Za-z_]+.

      Names are used in the definition and calling of procedures

      Returns:
      the parsed name
      Throws:
      Exception - if the captured token doesn't match the format for a name.
